H0.text: The toads were destroyed by the construction equipment that drained the wetland to build a mall, causing their disappearance from the area two years later.

H1.text: The toads died because toads cannot breathe out of water, so draining the wetland to build a mall removed the aquatic habitat that sustained them.

H2.text: The toads were frightened and went into the woods after the wetland was drained to build a mall, explaining their disappearance from the area two years later.

H3.text: The toads got their food from the wetland ecosystem, which was drained to build a mall, and two years later there were no more toads in that area.

A4.text: Amphibians such as frogs and salamanders need both terrestrial and aquatic habitats in which to reproduce and feed.

A5.text: This accumulation of toxicants will cause the biodiversity of a wetland to change, particularly since toxicants will be harmful to native aquatic species.

A6.text: When a habitat is destroyed, the carrying capacity for indigenous plants, animals, and other organisms is reduced so that populations decline, sometimes up to the level of extinction.

A7.text: More than 50% of wetlands in the U.S. have been destroyed in just the last 200 years.

A8.text: Human populations can impose excessive stresses on aquatic ecosystems.

A9.text: Human-made aquatic ecosystems, such as ditches, aquaculture ponds, and irrigation channels, may also cause harm to naturally occurring ecosystems by trading off biodiversity with their intended purposes.

A10.text: While tadpoles feed on algae, adult frogs forage on insects.

A11.text: Drainage of floodplains or development activities that narrow floodplain corridors reduces the ability of coupled river-floodplain systems to control flood damage.
